docs.abstract: “We’re not in a crisis yet, but all of the trends are in a bad direction,” said the insurance commissioner for California, which had to prevent insurers from abruptly dropping fire victims.
docs.snippet: “We’re not in a crisis yet, but all of the trends are in a bad direction,” said the insurance commissioner for California, which had to prevent insurers from abruptly dropping fire victims.
docs.lead_paragraph: California’s wildfires keep growing bigger, more frequent and more destructive. Of the 20 worst wildfires in state history, four were just last year, giving rise to a record $12.6 billion of insurance claims.

headline.main: How Wildfires Are Making Some California Homes Uninsurable
headline.print_headline: Wildfires Move California Closer to Insurance Crisis

docs.abstract: The Chinese authorities turned to a Massachusetts company and a prominent Yale researcher as they built an enormous system of surveillance and control.
docs.snippet: The Chinese authorities turned to a Massachusetts company and a prominent Yale researcher as they built an enormous system of surveillance and control.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The authorities called it a free health check. Tahir Imin had his doubts.

headline.main: China Uses DNA to Track Its People, With the Help of American Expertise
headline.print_headline: American DNA Expertise Helps Beijing Crack Down

docs.abstract: Studies consistently find that the 2017 law cut taxes for most Americans. Most of them don’t buy it.
docs.snippet: Studies consistently find that the 2017 law cut taxes for most Americans. Most of them don’t buy it.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you’re an American taxpayer, you probably got a tax cut last year. And there’s a good chance you don’t believe it.

headline.main: Face It: You (Probably) Got a Tax Cut
headline.print_headline: You Think You Didn’t Get a Tax Cut, but You’re Probably Wrong

byline.original: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

docs.abstract: Britain, New Zealand, Australia and other countries have grown increasingly worried about potential security risks related to the Chinese telecom giant.
docs.snippet: Britain, New Zealand, Australia and other countries have grown increasingly worried about potential security risks related to the Chinese telecom giant.
docs.lead_paragraph: It is one of China’s proudest corporate success stories, a colossus in cutting-edge technology that elbowed out Western rivals to become the biggest supplier of the hardware that connects our modern world.

headline.main: Arrest Shakes Huawei as Global Skepticism of Its Business Grows
headline.print_headline: Telecom Giant Sees Doors Slam Shut Across the Globe

byline.original: By Raymond Zhong and Li Yuan

docs.abstract: Behind the scenes, businesspeople worry that Beijing has become more interested in solidifying its control over people’s lives than promoting economic growth.
docs.snippet: Behind the scenes, businesspeople worry that Beijing has become more interested in solidifying its control over people’s lives than promoting economic growth.
docs.lead_paragraph: Chen Tianyong, a Chinese real estate developer in Shanghai, boarded a flight to Malta last month with no plans to return anytime soon.

headline.main: China’s Entrepreneurs Are Wary of Its Future
headline.print_headline: Entrepreneurs Wary About Direction of China

docs.abstract: Chinese tech entrepreneurs are rethinking their business trips and their American ties. They could instead be valuable allies in the drive to bring more freedom to China.
docs.snippet: Chinese tech entrepreneurs are rethinking their business trips and their American ties. They could instead be valuable allies in the drive to bring more freedom to China.
docs.lead_paragraph: Days after the Canadian authorities arrested one of China’s leading technology executives at the behest of Washington, Cisco warned some employees that China might return the favor.

headline.main: The Huawei Executive’s Arrest Is Igniting Fear. The U.S. Should Take Notice.
headline.print_headline: Huawei Bust Widely Seen  As Proxy Ploy Across China

docs.abstract: As wealthy millennial customers shift their money from goods to experiences, the world’s biggest luxury group is acquiring the company behind the Hotel Cipriani and Orient Express.
docs.snippet: As wealthy millennial customers shift their money from goods to experiences, the world’s biggest luxury group is acquiring the company behind the Hotel Cipriani and Orient Express.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Belmond, a fast-growing company based in London, offers its wealthy customers some of the most opulent travel experiences money can buy in settings like the Hotel Cipriani in Venice, the Copacabana Palace in Rio de Janeiro and Orient Express trains connecting major European cities.

headline.main: LVMH Buys Belmond, Luxury Hotel Owner, as Rich Shoppers Spend More on Travel
headline.print_headline: LVMH Snaps Up Belmond, a Luxury Travel Experiences Company

docs.abstract: Gucci removed a sweater that critics said evoked blackface imagery, while Adidas abandoned a white shoe it was marketing as part of a Black History Month tribute.
docs.snippet: Gucci removed a sweater that critics said evoked blackface imagery, while Adidas abandoned a white shoe it was marketing as part of a Black History Month tribute.
docs.lead_paragraph: Less than a week into Black History Month, in two episodes of retail déjà vu, Adidas and Gucci have apologized and pulled products criticized as racist.

headline.main: Gucci and Adidas Apologize and Drop Products Called Racist
headline.print_headline: Adidas and Gucci Apologize Over Products Called Racist

byline.original: By Tiffany Hsu and Elizabeth Paton

docs.abstract: Mr. Ghosn, the ousted Nissan executive, wasn’t supposed to succeed in Japan, but he never expected to fail like this. He faces charges of financial wrongdoing at the company he helped save.
docs.snippet: Mr. Ghosn, the ousted Nissan executive, wasn’t supposed to succeed in Japan, but he never expected to fail like this. He faces charges of financial wrongdoing at the company he helped save.
docs.lead_paragraph: Carlos Ghosn was tired. At 64 years old, the chairman of an auto empire that spanned several continents and included Nissan, Renault and Mitsubishi wasn’t bouncing back from jet lag the way he used to. Melatonin wasn’t working anymore, and he had bouts of insomnia, phoning his children in the middle of the night or going on long walks around his Tokyo or Paris neighborhood. He planned to retire soon, stepping back from spending his life on an airplane, albeit a luxurious one paid for by Nissan.

headline.main: The Rise and Fall of Carlos Ghosn
headline.print_headline: Stunning Fall of Nissan’s Brash Savior

byline.original: By Amy Chozick and Motoko Rich
